comments: Physical electronics of semiconductor devices. Energy bands in solids. Statistics governing the charge carriers in semiconductors. Equilibrium and non-equilibrium transport phenomena in semiconductors. Operation and equivalent circuits for the pn junction, bipolar and field effect transistor, and other semiconductor devices. Scaling issues in transistors and introduction to next-generation nanotechnologies.  Students differed in their opinions of the class organization; some thought it was extremely disorganized and chaotic while others thought it worked well, saying that they would not change a thing. Several felt that material “wasn’t pleasant” and that the course required a lot of work for a 200-level class.   Dr. Piazza was “a great professor,” working hard to keep the class interested, awake, and excited, while trying to effectively convey the subject material.   It was agreed that lectures could be dry at times, but exams were very fair. Many students felt that homework problem sets needed improvement but that practice problems were extremely beneficial.
